meaningMnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

峠 refers to a mountain pass, and often specifically the highest point of a <vocabulary>mountain pass</vocabulary>, where it passes between two mountains. When used figuratively, it means <vocabulary>the worst</vocabulary>, as in the toughest moment of a specific event, like the height of a health crisis or the hottest day of a heatwave.
readingMnemonic: You climb along the <vocabulary>mountain pass</vocabulary> and see adorable little <reading>To</reading>kyo <reading>ge</reading>ckos (とうげ) climbing all over the place. They're climbing with you now!
